description: A studdy on aer, the aspect of air and wind.  As a fundamental aspect, it can not be created from combining other aspects.  It is commonly found in objects with ties to air, or that has been exposed to wind.  Crystalized aer can be extracted by connecting two containers with a hose or pipe.  One of the containers are filled with aer rich materials and then heated.  The aer will sublimate, travel to the other cooler container, and then desublimate, resulting in yellow crystal.  Chewing on them seems to fill your lungs with air, which seems potentially useful when dealing with smoke or underwater enviroments.  It seems to be potentially possible to infuse items with these crystals to make them lighter.
A studdy on alienis, the aspect of eldritch and ailien.

A studdy on aqua, the aspect of water.  As a fundamental aspect, it can not be created from combining other aspects.  It is most commonly found in water, naturally.  Crystals can be extracted by letting a container of clean water slowly evaporate until only blue crystals remains at the bottom.  Chewing on them slakes your thirst, making them a potentailly convinient way of carrying drinking water.  Infusing objects with the crystals seems to make them more liquid, which might prove useful.
A studdy on arbor, the aspect of trees.
A studdy on auram, the aspect of the aura.
A studdy on bestia, the aspect of animals.
A studdy on cognito, the aspect of mind, knowledge, and information.
A studdy on corpus, the aspect of flesh, blood, skin, and bone.
A studdy on exanimis, the aspect of undeath.
A studdy on fabrico, the aspect of crafting and repairing.
A studdy on fames, the aspect of food and hunger.
A studdy on gelum, the aspect of cold and ice.
A studdy on herba, the aspect of plants.

A studdy on ignis, the aspect of fire.  As a fundamental aspect, it can not be created from combining other aspects.  It is most commonly found in water, naturally.  Crystals can be extracted by letting a container of clean water slowly evaporate until only blue crystals remains at the bottom.  Chewing on them slakes your thirst, making them a potentailly convinient way of carrying drinking water.  Infusing objects with the crystals seems to make them more liquid, which might prove useful.
